doc.title: Italian judges to go on strike
doc.author: John Hooper
doc.description: Italy's judges and prosecutors are to go on strike in protest at a proposed reform of the legal system by Silvio Berlusconi's centre-right government.

main.p: Italy's judges and prosecutors are to go on strike in protest at a proposed reform of the legal system by Silvio Berlusconi's centre-right government which one of their leaders said yesterday "laid the basis for an attempt to 'fascistify' the judiciary".

Winding up a conference of Italy's national magistrates association, its general secretary, Carlo Fucci, said a bill being debated by parliament was reminiscent of one passed at the start of Benito Mussolini's dictatorship, which put the courts at the service of the regime. A strike was needed to defend the independence of Italy's judiciary, which was "in serious danger". No dates have been set for the action.
The head of Mr Berlusconi's Forza Italia party, Sandro Bondi, said Mr Fucci's speech merely proved his party's allegations that Italy suffered from a politicised judiciary.
The proposed law advocates limiting the independence of individual prosecutors and making them subject to a structure that critics say would be easier for the government to control.
